ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A very good working knowledge of the Homeric Greek dialect, in addition to lots of great literary and historical commentary on the Homeric Epics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The syllabus was well chosen, and the workload was just enough to be challenging without ever being overwhelming. I think that it would have been nice to have more engagement with the Iliad, but I understand the limitations of the course and the need to focus on a singular work. 

I did feel, however, that the length of the quizzes was never quite right. This is the only class I've taken where I've felt that I consistently haven't had enough time even to write down my answers on regular assignments, and I think that slightly shortened quizzes wouldn't detract anything from the class but would only make the actual process of evaluation more manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're even thinking of this course, you should take it, as it will open up the whole world of Homeric Greek for you. It not only gives you a great linguistic experience, but also allows you to read some truly fantastic literature in the original language.
Definitely. I learned a lot from this course, and our professor Pauline LeVen was amazing throughout the semester.
